After the collapse of the Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia (SFRY), the remaining republics of Montenegro and Serbia agreed to the formation of the Federal R

entities.title: Montenegrin independence referendum, 2006
entities.description: An independence referendum was held in Montenegro on 21 May 2006. It was approved by 55.5% of voters, narrowly passing the 55% threshold. By 23 May, preliminary referendum results were recognized by all five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council, suggesting widespread international recognition if Montenegro were to become formally independent. On 31 May, the referendum commissio

entities.title: State Union of Serbia and Montenegro
entities.description: The Federal Republic of Yugoslavia, commonly referred to as FR Yugoslavia or simply Yugoslavia, was a country in the Balkans, which came into existence in 1992, following the breakup of the SFR Yugoslavia. It comprised the Republic of Serbia and the Republic of Montenegro, the two remaining republics of Yugoslavia. In February 2003, FR Yugoslavia was transformed from a federal republic to a politi

heading: Events
txt: JAXA, the Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency, launches the solar-sail spacecraft IKAROS aboard an H-IIA rocket. The vessel would make a Venus flyby late in the year.

entities.title: Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency
entities.description: The Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency (JAXA)  is the Japanese national aerospace and space agency. Through the merger of three previously independent organizations, JAXA was formed on 1 October 2003. JAXA is responsible for research, technology development and launch of satellites into orbit, and is involved in many more advanced missions such as asteroid exploration and possible human exploratio

entities.title: Solar-sail
entities.description: Solar sails are a method of spacecraft propulsion using radiation pressure exerted by sunlight on large mirrors. A number of spaceflight missions to test solar propulsion and navigation have been proposed since the 1980s. The first spacecraft to make use of the technology was IKAROS, launched in 2010.

entities.title: IKAROS
entities.description: IKAROS is a Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency (JAXA) experimental spacecraft. The spacecraft was launched on 20 May 2010, aboard an H-IIA rocket, together with the Akatsuki probe and four other small spacecraft. IKAROS is the first spacecraft to successfully demonstrate solar sail technology in interplanetary space.

entities.title: H-IIA
entities.description: H-IIA (H-2A) is an active expendable launch system operated by Mitsubishi Heavy Industries (MHI) for the Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency. These liquid fuel rockets have been used to launch satellites into geostationary orbit; lunar orbiting spacecraft; Akatsuki, which studied the planet Venus; and the Emirates Mars Mission, which was launched to Mars in July 2020. Launches occur at the Tanegash

heading: Events
txt: Radio broadcaster Harold Camping predicted that the world would end on this date.

entities.title: Harold Camping
entities.description: Harold Egbert Camping was an American Christian radio broadcaster and evangelist. Beginning in 1958, he served as president of Family Radio, a California-based radio station group that, at its peak, broadcast to more than 150 markets in the United States. In October 2011, he retired from active broadcasting following a stroke, but still maintained a role at Family Radio until his death. Camping is

entities.title: 2011 end times prediction
entities.description: American Christian radio host Harold Camping stated that the Rapture and Judgment Day would take place on May 21, 2011, and that the end of the world would take place five months later on October 21, 2011.

heading: Events
txt: A bus accident near Himara, Albania kills 13 people and injures 21 others.

entities.title: Qafa e Vishës bus accident
entities.description: The Qafa e Vishës bus accident occurred on 21 May 2012, at Qafa e Vishës near Himarë, Albania, when a bus plunged 80 metres (260 ft) off a cliff. Most of the victims were students of Aleksandër Xhuvani University of Elbasan. The driver is also believed to have been killed. The students were travelling from Elbasan to Saranda.

entities.title: Himara
entities.description: Himara or Himarë is a bilingual region and municipality in southern Albania, part of Vlorë County. It lies between the Ceraunian Mountains and the Ionian Sea and is part of the Albanian Riviera. The region consists of the town of Himarë and the villages of Dhërmi, Pilur, Kudhës, Qeparo, Vuno, Ilias, and Palasë. The municipality was formed at the 2015 local government reform by the merger of the fo

heading: Events
txt: A suicide bombing kills more than 120 people in Sana'a, Yemen.

entities.title: Sana'a
entities.description: Sanaa, also spelled Sanaʽa or Sana, is the largest city in Yemen and the centre of Sanaa Governorate. The city is not part of the Governorate, but forms the separate administrative district of "Amanat Al-Asemah". Under the Yemeni constitution, Sanaʽa is the capital of the country, although the seat of the Yemeni government moved to Aden, the former capital of South Yemen in the aftermath of the Ho

heading: Events
txt: Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus performed their final show at Nassau Veterans Memorial Coliseum.

entities.title: Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus
entities.description: Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus, also known as the Ringling Bros. Circus, Barnum & Bailey Circus, Ringling Bros., Barnum & Bailey or simply Ringling was an American traveling circus company billed as The Greatest Show on Earth. It and its predecessor shows ran from 1871 to 2017. Known as Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Combined Shows, the circus started in 1919 when the Barnum & Baile

heading: Births
txt: Albrecht Dürer, German painter, engraver, and mathematician (d. 1528)

entities.title: Albrecht Dürer
entities.description: Albrecht Dürer, sometimes spelled in English as Durer or Duerer, was a German painter, printmaker, and theorist of the German Renaissance. Born in Nuremberg, Dürer established his reputation and influence across Europe in his twenties due to his high-quality woodcut prints. He was in contact with the major Italian artists of his time, including Raphael, Giovanni Bellini and Leonardo da Vinci, and

heading: Births
txt: Al-Hattab, Muslim jurist (d. 1547)

entities.title: Al-Hattab
entities.description: Muhammad Abu 'Abd Allah ibn Muhammad at-Tarabulsi al-Hattab al-Ru'yani, more commonly referred to in Islamic scholarship as al-Hattab or Imam al-Hattab, was a 16th-century CE Muslim jurist from Tripoli, the capital of modern-day Libya. Al-Hattab was a scholar of the Maliki school of Islamic jurisprudence (fiqh). His book Mawahib al-Jalil, which was one of the first major commentaries on Khalil's M

heading: Births
txt: Philip II of Spain (d. 1598)

entities.title: Philip II of Spain
entities.description: Philip II was King of Spain (1556–1598), King of Portugal, King of Naples and Sicily, and jure uxoris King of England and Ireland. He was also Duke of Milan from 1540. From 1555 he was Lord of the Seventeen Provinces of the Netherlands.

heading: Births
txt: Eleonore of Austria, Queen of Poland (d. 1697)

entities.title: Eleonore of Austria, Queen of Poland
entities.description: Eleonore Maria Josefa of Austria was Queen of Poland by marriage to king Michał Korybut Wiśniowiecki and Duchess of Lorraine by marriage to Charles V, Duke of Lorraine.

heading: Births
txt: Alexander Pope, English poet, essayist, and translator (d. 1744)

entities.title: Alexander Pope
entities.description: Alexander Pope was a poet and satirist of the Augustan period and one of its greatest artistic exponents. He is considered the foremost English poet of the early 18th century and a master of the heroic couplet. Pope is best known for satirical and discursive poetry, including The Rape of the Lock, The Dunciad, and An Essay on Criticism, and for his translation of Homer. After Shakespeare, he is th

heading: Births
txt: Alfred Moore, American lawyer and judge (d. 1810)

entities.title: Alfred Moore
entities.description: Alfred Moore was a North Carolina judge who became an associate justice of the Supreme Court of the United States. Moore Square, a park located in the Moore Square Historic District in Raleigh, North Carolina was named in his honor, as was Moore County, established in 1784, also in the state of North Carolina.

heading: Births
txt: William Babington, Irish-born, English physician and mineralogist (d. 1833)

entities.title: William Babington (physician)
entities.description: William Babington FRS FGS was an Anglo-Irish physician and mineralogist.

entities.title: Physician
entities.description: A physician, medical practitioner, medical doctor, or simply doctor, is a professional who practices medicine, which is concerned with promoting, maintaining or restoring health through the study, diagnosis, prognosis and treatment of disease, injury, and other physical and mental impairments. Physicians may focus their practice on certain disease categories, types of patients, and methods of trea

entities.title: Mineralogy
entities.description: Mineralogy is a subject of geology specializing in the scientific study of the chemistry, crystal structure, and physical properties of minerals and mineralized artifacts. Specific studies within mineralogy include the processes of mineral origin and formation, classification of minerals, their geographical distribution, as well as their utilization.

heading: Births
txt: Joseph Fouché, French lawyer and politician (d. 1820)

entities.title: Joseph Fouché
entities.description: Joseph Fouché, 1st Duc d'Otrante, 1st Comte Fouché was a French statesman, revolutionary, and Minister of Police under First Consul Napoleon Bonaparte, who later became Emperor Napoleon. He was particularly known for the ferocity with which he suppressed the Lyon insurrection during the Revolution in 1793 and for being minister of police under the Directory, the Consulate, and the Empire. In Engli

heading: Births
txt: Lucien Bonaparte, French soldier and politician (d. 1840)

entities.title: Lucien Bonaparte
entities.description: Lucien Bonaparte, Prince Français, 1st Prince of Canino and Musignano, the third surviving son of Carlo Bonaparte and his wife Letizia Ramolino, was a French statesman, who served as the final President of the Council of Five Hundred at the end of the French Revolution.

heading: Births
txt: Elizabeth Fry, English prison reformer, philanthropist and Quaker (d. 1845)

entities.title: Elizabeth Fry
entities.description: Elizabeth Fry, sometimes referred to as Betsy Fry, was an English prison reformer, social reformer and, as a Quaker, a Christian philanthropist. She has been called the "angel of prisons".

heading: Births
txt: William Cavendish, 6th Duke of Devonshire, English politician, Lord Chamberlain of the Household (d. 1858)

entities.title: William Cavendish, 6th Duke of Devonshire
entities.description: William George Spencer Cavendish, 6th Duke of Devonshire,, styled Marquess of Hartington until 1811, was a British peer, courtier, nobleman, and Whig politician. Known as the "Bachelor Duke", he was Lord Chamberlain of the Household between 1827 and 1828 and again between 1830 and 1834. The Cavendish banana is named after him.

entities.title: Lord Chamberlain
entities.description: The Lord Chamberlain or Lord Chamberlain of the Household is the most senior officer of the Royal Household of the United Kingdom, supervising the departments which support and provide advice to the Sovereign of the United Kingdom while also acting as the main channel of communication between the Sovereign and the House of Lords. The office organises all ceremonial activity such as garden parties,

heading: Births
txt: Gaspard-Gustave de Coriolis, French mathematician and engineer (d. 1843)

entities.title: Gaspard-Gustave de Coriolis
entities.description: Gaspard-Gustave de Coriolis was a French mathematician, mechanical engineer and scientist. He is best known for his work on the supplementary forces that are detected in a rotating frame of reference, leading to the Coriolis effect. He was the first to apply the term travail for the transfer of energy by a force acting through a distance.

heading: Births
txt: Mary Anning, English paleontologist (d. 1847)

entities.title: Mary Anning
entities.description: Mary Anning was an English fossil collector, dealer, and palaeontologist who became known around the world for finds she made in Jurassic marine fossil beds in the cliffs along the English Channel at Lyme Regis in the county of Dorset in Southwest England. Anning's findings contributed to changes in scientific thinking about prehistoric life and the history of the Earth.

heading: Births
txt: Princess Sophie of Sweden, Swedish princess (d. 1865)

entities.title: Princess Sophie of Sweden
entities.description: Princess Sophie of Sweden was, by marriage, Grand Duchess of Baden as the wife of sovereign Grand Duke of Baden, Leopold.

heading: Births
txt: Harriet Sutherland-Leveson-Gower, Duchess of Sutherland, English duchess (d. 1868)

entities.title: Harriet Sutherland-Leveson-Gower, Duchess of Sutherland
entities.description: Harriet Elizabeth Georgiana Sutherland-Leveson-Gower, Duchess of Sutherland, styled The Honourable Harriet Howard before her marriage, was Mistress of the Robes under several Whig administrations: 1837–1841, 1846–1852, 1853–1858, and 1859–1861; and a great friend of Queen Victoria. She was an important figure in London's high society, and used her social position to undertake various philanthropic

heading: Births
txt: David de Jahacob Lopez Cardozo, Dutch Talmudist (d. 1890)

entities.title: David de Jahacob Lopez Cardozo
entities.description: David de Jahacob Lopez Cardozo was a Dutch Talmudist and prominent communal worker. He was sent at an early age to the celebrated bet ha-midrash 'Etz Chayyim, studied under Rabbi Berenstein at The Hague, and received his diploma of "Morenu" in 1839. The same year he was appointed ab bet din of the Portuguese synagogue of Amsterdam, and in 1852 ab bet din and preacher of that synagogue, Aron Mendes

heading: Births
txt: William P. Sprague, American banker and politician (d. 1899)

entities.title: William P. Sprague
entities.description: William Peter Sprague was a businessman, banker, politician, and a two-term U.S. Representative from Ohio.

heading: Births
txt: Rudolf Koller, Swiss painter (d. 1905)

entities.title: Rudolf Koller
entities.description:
Rudolf Koller was a Swiss painter. He is associated with a realist and classicist style, and also with the essentially romantic Düsseldorf school of painting. Koller's style is similar to that of the realist painters Gustave Courbet and Jean-Baptiste-Camille Corot. Considered Switzerland's finest animal painter, Koller is rated alongside George Stubbs, Rosa Bonheur and Théodore Géricault. 
While h

heading: Births
txt: František Chvostek, Czech-Austrian physician and academic (d. 1884)

entities.title: František Chvostek
entities.description: František Chvostek was a Czech-Austrian military physician. He is most notable for having described Chvostek's sign which he described in 1876.

heading: Births
txt: Itagaki Taisuke, Japanese soldier and politician (d. 1919)

entities.title: Itagaki Taisuke
entities.description: Count Itagaki Taisuke  was a Japanese soldier, politician and leader of the Freedom and People's Rights Movement , which evolved into Japan's first political party. His image is on Japan's 1953 100-yen banknote.

heading: Births
txt: Charles Albert Gobat, Swiss lawyer and politician, and Nobel Prize laureate (d. 1914)

entities.title: Charles Albert Gobat
entities.description: Charles Albert Gobat was a Swiss lawyer, educational administrator, and politician who jointly received the Nobel Peace Prize with Élie Ducommun in 1902 for their leadership of the Permanent International Peace Bureau.

entities.title: Nobel Peace Prize
entities.description: The Nobel Peace Prize is one of the five Nobel Prizes established by the will of Swedish industrialist, inventor, and armaments manufacturer Alfred Nobel, along with the prizes in Chemistry, Physics, Physiology or Medicine, and Literature. Since March 1901, it has been awarded annually to those who have "done the most or the best work for fraternity between nations, for the abolition or reduction

heading: Births
txt: Louis Renault, French jurist, educator, and Nobel Prize laureate (d. 1918)

entities.title: Nobel Peace Prize
entities.description: The Nobel Peace Prize is one of the five Nobel Prizes established by the will of Swedish industrialist, inventor, and armaments manufacturer Alfred Nobel, along with the prizes in Chemistry, Physics, Physiology or Medicine, and Literature. Since March 1901, it has been awarded annually to those who have "done the most or the best work for fraternity between nations, for the abolition or reduction

heading: Births
txt: Henri Rousseau, French painter (d. 1910)

entities.title: Henri Rousseau
entities.description: Henri Julien Félix Rousseau was a French post-impressionist painter in the Naïve or Primitive manner. He was also known as Le Douanier, a humorous description of his occupation as a toll and tax collector. He started painting seriously in his early forties; by age 49, he retired from his job to work on his art full-time.

heading: Births
txt: Giuseppe Mercalli, Italian priest and volcanologist (d. 1914)

entities.title: Giuseppe Mercalli
entities.description: Giuseppe Mercalli was an Italian volcanologist and Catholic priest. He is known best for the Mercalli intensity scale for measuring earthquake intensity.

heading: Births
txt: Léon Bourgeois, French police officer and politician, 64th Prime Minister of France, Nobel Prize laureate (d. 1925)

entities.title: Léon Bourgeois
entities.description: Léon Victor Auguste Bourgeois was a French statesman. His ideas influenced the Radical Party regarding a wide range of issues. He promoted progressive taxation such as progressive income taxes and social insurance schemes, along with economic equality, expanded educational opportunities, and cooperative solidarism. In foreign policy, he called for a strong League of Nations, and the maintenance of

entities.title: Prime Minister of France
entities.description: The prime minister of the French Republic, sometimes shortened to premier, is the head of government of France. During the Third and Fourth Republics, the head of government was formally called president of the Council of Ministers, generally shortened to president of the Council. However, the post was usually called "prime minister" or "premier" in non-French sources. The prime minister is the ho

entities.title: Nobel Peace Prize
entities.description: The Nobel Peace Prize is one of the five Nobel Prizes established by the will of Swedish industrialist, inventor, and armaments manufacturer Alfred Nobel, along with the prizes in Chemistry, Physics, Physiology or Medicine, and Literature. Since March 1901, it has been awarded annually to those who have "done the most or the best work for fraternity between nations, for the abolition or reduction

heading: Births
txt: Jacques Marie Eugène Godefroy Cavaignac, French politician (d. 1905)

entities.title: Jacques Marie Eugène Godefroy Cavaignac
entities.description: Jacques Marie Eugène Godefroy Cavaignac, known as Godefroy Cavaignac, French politician, was born in Paris. He was the son of Louis Eugène Cavaignac. He made public profession of his republican principles as a schoolboy at the Lycée Charlemagne by refusing in 1867 to receive a prize at the Sorbonne from the hand of the prince imperial.

heading: Births
txt: José Batlle y Ordóñez, Uruguayan journalist and politician, President of Uruguay (d. 1929)

entities.title: José Batlle y Ordóñez
entities.description: José Pablo Torcuato Batlle y Ordóñez, nicknamed Don Pepe, was a prominent Uruguayan politician, who served two terms as President of Uruguay for the Colorado Party. He was the son of a former president and was widely praised for his introduction of his political system, Batllism, to South America and for his role in modernizing Uruguay through his creation of extensive welfare state reforms.

entities.title: President of Uruguay

entities.title: West Francia
entities.description: In medieval history, West Francia or the Kingdom of the West Franks refers to the western part of the Frankish Empire established by Charlemagne. It represents the earliest stage of the Kingdom of France, lasting from about 840 until 987. West Francia emerged from the partition of the Carolingian Empire in 843 under the Treaty of Verdun following the death of Charlemagne's son, Louis the Pious.

entities.title: Magdeburg Hemispheres
entities.description: The Magdeburg hemispheres are a pair of large copper hemispheres, with mating rims. They were used to demonstrate the power of atmospheric pressure. When the rims were sealed with grease and the air was pumped out, the sphere contained a vacuum and could not be pulled apart by teams of horses. The Magdeburg hemispheres were invented by German scientist and mayor of Magdeburg, Otto von Guericke, to

heading: Deaths
txt: John Eliot, English-American minister and missionary (b. 1604)

entities.title: John Eliot (missionary)
entities.description: John Eliot was a Puritan missionary to the American Indians who some called "the apostle to the Indians" and the founder of Roxbury Latin School in the Massachusetts Bay Colony in 1645.

heading: Deaths
txt: Pierre Poiret, French mystic and philosopher (b. 1646)

entities.title: Pierre Poiret
entities.description: Pierre Poiret Naudé was a prominent French mystic and Christian philosopher. He was born in Metz and died in Rijnsburg.

heading: Deaths
txt: Robert Harley, 1st Earl of Oxford and Earl Mortimer, English politician, Chancellor of the Exchequer (b. 1661)

entities.title: Robert Harley, 1st Earl of Oxford and Earl Mortimer
entities.description: Robert Harley, 1st Earl of Oxford and Earl Mortimer, KG PC FRS was an English and later British statesman of the late Stuart and early Georgian periods. He began his career as a Whig, before defecting to a new Tory Ministry. He was raised to the peerage of Great Britain as an earl in 1711. Between 1711 and 1714 he served as Lord High Treasurer, effectively Queen Anne's chief minister. He has been

entities.title: Chancellor of the Exchequer
entities.description: The Chancellor of the Exchequer, often abbreviated to the Chancellor, is a high ranking Minister of the Crown within the Government of the United Kingdom, and head of Her Majesty's Treasury. As one of the four Great Offices of State, the chancellor is a senior member of the British Cabinet.

heading: Deaths
txt: Lars Roberg, Swedish physician and academic (b. 1664)

entities.title: Lars Roberg
entities.description: Lars Roberg was a Swedish physician and natural science researcher. He served as a professor of anatomy and medicine at Uppsala University.

heading: Deaths
txt: Alexander Joseph Sulkowski, Polish and Saxon general (b. 1695)

entities.title: Alexander Joseph Sulkowski
entities.description: Alexander Joseph Sulkowski was a Saxon-Polish general and the progenitor of the Sułkowski noble line.

heading: Deaths
txt: Christopher Smart, English actor, playwright, and poet (b. 1722)

entities.title: Christopher Smart
entities.description: Christopher Smart was an English poet.

heading: Deaths
txt: Carl Wilhelm Scheele, German-Swedish chemist and pharmacist (b. 1742)

entities.title: Carl Wilhelm Scheele
entities.description: Carl Wilhelm Scheele was a German and Swedish Pomeranian pharmaceutical chemist.

heading: Deaths
txt: Thomas Warton, English poet and critic (b. 1728)

entities.title: Thomas Warton
entities.description: Thomas Warton was an English literary historian, critic, and poet. He was appointed Poet Laureate in 1785, following the death of William Whitehead (poet). He is sometimes called Thomas Warton the younger to distinguish him from his father Thomas Warton the elder. His most famous poem is The Pleasures of Melancholy, a representative work of the Graveyard poets.

heading: Deaths
txt: Chevalier d'Eon, French diplomat and spy (b. 1728)

entities.title: Chevalier d'Eon
entities.description: Charles-Geneviève-Louis-Auguste-André-Timothée d'Éon de Beaumont, usually known as the Chevalier d'Éon, was a French diplomat, spy, and soldier. D'Éon fought in the Seven Years' War, and spied for France while in Russia and England. D'Éon had androgynous physical characteristics and natural abilities as a mimic and a spy. D'Éon appeared publicly as a man and pursued masculine occupations for 49 ye

heading: Deaths
txt: Sikandar Jah, 3rd Nizam (b. 1768)

entities.title: Sikandar Jah
entities.description: Nawab Mir Akbar Ali Khan Bahadur, Sikander Jah, Asaf Jah III, was the 3rd Nizam/Ruler of Hyderabad, India from 1803 to 1829.

heading: Deaths
txt: Giuseppe Baini, Italian priest and composer (b. 1775)

entities.title: Giuseppe Baini
entities.description: Abbate Giuseppe Baini was an Italian priest, music critic, conductor, and composer of church music.

heading: Deaths
txt: José de la Riva Agüero, Peruvian soldier and politician, 1st President of Peru and 2nd President of North Peru (b. 1783)

entities.title: José de la Riva Agüero
entities.description: José Mariano de la Cruz de la Riva Agüero y Sánchez Boquete Marquess De Montealegre de Aulestia was a soldier, politician, and historian who served as the 1st President of Peru and 2nd President of North Peru. He was the first Head of State who had the title of President of the Republic.

heading: Deaths
txt: John Drew, Irish-American actor and manager (b. 1827)

entities.title: John Drew (actor)
entities.description: John Drew was an Irish-American stage actor and theatre manager.

heading: Deaths
txt: Arturo Prat, Chilean lawyer and commander (b. 1848)

entities.title: Arturo Prat
entities.description: Agustín Arturo Prat Chacón was a Chilean lawyer and navy officer. He was killed in the Battle of Iquique, during the War of the Pacific.

heading: Deaths
txt: Émile Henry, French anarchist (b. 1872)

entities.title: Émile Henry (anarchist)
entities.description: Émile Henry was a French anarchist, who on 12 February 1894 detonated a bomb at the Café Terminus in the Parisian Gare Saint-Lazare killing one person and wounding twenty.

heading: Deaths
txt: August Kundt, German physicist and academic (b. 1839)

heading: Deaths
txt: Franz von Suppé, Austrian composer and conductor (b. 1819)

entities.title: Franz von Suppé
entities.description: Franz von Suppé was an Austrian composer of light operas and other theatre music. He came from the Kingdom of Dalmatia, Austro-Hungarian Empire. A composer and conductor of the Romantic period, he is notable for his four dozen operettas.

heading: Deaths
txt: Joseph Olivier, French rugby player (b. 1874)

entities.title: Joseph Olivier (rugby union)
entities.description: Joseph Olivier was a French rugby union player who competed in the 1900 Summer Olympics. He was a member of the French rugby union team, which won the gold medal.

heading: Deaths
txt: Williamina Fleming, Scottish-American astronomer and academic (b. 1857)

entities.title: Williamina Fleming
entities.description: Williamina Paton Stevens Fleming was a Scottish astronomer active in the United States. During her career, she helped develop a common designation system for stars and cataloged thousands of stars and other astronomical phenomena. Among several career achievements that advanced astronomy, Fleming is noted for her discovery of the Horsehead Nebula in 1888.

heading: Deaths
txt: Leonid Gobyato, Russian general and engineer (b. 1875)

entities.title: Leonid Gobyato
entities.description: Leonid Nikolaevich Gobyato was a lieutenant-general in the Imperial Russian Army and designer of the modern, man-portable mortar.

heading: Deaths
txt: Evgraf Fedorov, Russian mathematician, crystallographer, and mineralogist (b. 1853)

entities.title: Evgraf Fedorov
entities.description: Evgraf Stepanovich Fedorov was a Russian mathematician, crystallographer and mineralogist.

heading: Deaths
txt: Venustiano Carranza, Mexican politician, 54th President of Mexico (b. 1859)

entities.title: Venustiano Carranza
entities.description: José Venustiano Carranza De La Garza was one of the main leaders of the Mexican Revolution, whose victorious northern revolutionary Constitutionalist Army defeated the counter-revolutionary regime of Victoriano Huerta and then defeated fellow revolutionaries after Huerta's ouster. He secured power in Mexico, serving as head of state from 1914 to 1916. With the promulgation of a new revolutionary M

entities.title: President of Mexico
entities.description: The president of Mexico, officially known as the president of the United Mexican States, is the head of state and head of government of Mexico. Under the Constitution of Mexico, the President is the chief of the executive branch of the federal government and is the commander in chief of the Mexican Armed Forces. The current president is Andrés Manuel López Obrador, who took office on 1 December 20

heading: Deaths
txt: Hidesaburō Ueno, Japanese agriculturalist, guardian of Hachikō (b. 1871)

entities.title: Hidesaburō Ueno
entities.description: Hidesaburō Ueno  was a Japanese agricultural scientist, famous in Japan as the guardian of Hachikō, a devoted Akita dog.

entities.title: Hachikō
entities.description: Hachikō  was a Japanese Akita dog remembered for his remarkable loyalty to his owner, Hidesaburō Ueno, for whom he continued to wait for over nine years following Ueno's death.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ronald Firbank, English-Italian author (b. 1886)

entities.title: Ronald Firbank
entities.description: Arthur Annesley Ronald Firbank was an innovative English novelist. His eight short novels, partly inspired by the London aesthetes of the 1890s, especially Oscar Wilde, consist largely of dialogue, with references to religion, social-climbing, and sexuality.

heading: Deaths
txt: Archibald Primrose, 5th Earl of Rosebery, English politician, Prime Minister of the United Kingdom (b. 1847)

entities.title: Archibald Primrose, 5th Earl of Rosebery
entities.description: Archibald Philip Primrose, 5th Earl of Rosebery, 1st Earl of Midlothian, was a British Liberal politician who served as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from March 1894 to June 1895. Between the death of his father, in 1851, and the death of his grandfather, the 4th Earl of Rosebery, in 1868, he was known by the courtesy title of Lord Dalmeny.

entities.title: Prime Minister of the United Kingdom
entities.description: The prime minister of the United Kingdom is the head of government in the United Kingdom. The prime minister chairs the Cabinet and selects its ministers, and advises the sovereign on the exercise of much of the Royal Prerogative. As modern prime ministers hold office by virtue of their ability to command the confidence of the House of Commons, they typically sit as a Member of Parliament and lead

heading: Deaths
txt: Marcel Boulenger, French fencer and author (b. 1873)

entities.title: Marcel Boulenger
entities.description: Marcel Jacques Amand Romain Boulenger was a French novelist and fencer who competed in fencing in the late 19th century and early 20th century.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jane Addams, American activist and author, co-founded Hull House, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1860)

entities.title: Jane Addams
entities.description: Jane Addams was an American settlement activist, reformer, social worker, sociologist, public administrator and author. She was an important leader in the history of social work and women's suffrage in the United States and advocated for world peace. She co-founded Chicago's Hull House, one of America's most famous settlement houses. In 1910, Addams was awarded an honorary master of arts degree fr

entities.title: Hull House
entities.description: Hull House was a settlement house in Chicago, Illinois, United States that was co-founded in 1889 by Jane Addams and Ellen Gates Starr. Located on the Near West Side of the city, Hull House opened to serve recently arrived European immigrants. By 1911, Hull House had expanded to 13 buildings. In 1912 the Hull House complex was completed with the addition of a summer camp, the Bowen Country Club. W

entities.title: Nobel Peace Prize
entities.description: The Nobel Peace Prize is one of the five Nobel Prizes established by the will of Swedish industrialist, inventor, and armaments manufacturer Alfred Nobel, along with the prizes in Chemistry, Physics, Physiology or Medicine, and Literature. Since March 1901, it has been awarded annually to those who have "done the most or the best work for fraternity between nations, for the abolition or reduction

heading: Deaths
txt: Hugo de Vries, Dutch botanist and geneticist (b. 1848)

heading: Deaths
txt: Billy Minter, English footballer and manager (b. 1888)

entities.title: Billy Minter
entities.description: William James Minter, was a player, trainer, manager and assistant secretary at Tottenham Hotspur. He scored 101 goals for Tottenham, and was for a time the top scorer for the club. He also managed the club for three years, and after he resigned as manager he stayed at the club until his death in 1940.

heading: Deaths
txt: Klaus Mann, German-American novelist, playwright, and critic (b. 1906)

entities.title: Klaus Mann
entities.description: Klaus Heinrich Thomas Mann was a German-born American writer and dissident. He was the son of Thomas Mann and brother of Erika Mann, with whom he maintained a lifelong close relationship, and Golo Mann. He is well known for his 1936 novel, Mephisto.

heading: Deaths
txt: John Garfield, American actor (b. 1913)

entities.title: John Garfield
entities.description: John Garfield was an American actor who played brooding, rebellious, working-class characters. He grew up in poverty in New York City. In the early 1930s, he became a member of the Group Theater. In 1937, he moved to Hollywood, eventually becoming one of Warner Bros.' stars. He received Academy Award nominations for his performances in Four Daughters (1938) and Body and Soul (1947).

heading: Deaths
txt: Harry Bensley, English businessman and adventurer (b. 1877)

entities.title: Harry Bensley
entities.description: Harry Bensley was an English rake and adventurer, best remembered as the subject of an extraordinary wager between John Pierpont Morgan and Hugh Cecil Lowther, 5th Earl of Lonsdale. How much of his story is based on fact is unclear.

heading: Deaths
txt: Alexander Vertinsky, Ukrainian-Russian singer-songwriter, actor, and poet (b. 1889)

entities.title: Alexander Vertinsky
entities.description: Alexander Nikolayevich Vertinsky was Russian and Soviet artist, poet, singer, composer, cabaret artist and actor who exerted seminal influence on the Russian tradition of artistic singing.

heading: Deaths
txt: James Franck, German physicist and academic, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1882)

entities.title: James Franck
entities.description: James Franck was a German physicist who won the 1925 Nobel Prize for Physics with Gustav Hertz "for their discovery of the laws governing the impact of an electron upon an atom". He completed his doctorate in 1906 and his habilitation in 1911 at the Frederick William University in Berlin, where he lectured and taught until 1918, having reached the position of professor extraordinarius. He served a

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Physics
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Physics is a yearly award given by the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences for those who have made the most outstanding contributions for mankind in the field of physics. It is one of the five Nobel Prizes established by the will of Alfred Nobel in 1895 and awarded since 1901; the others being the Nobel Prize in Chemistry, Nobel Prize in Literature, Nobel Peace Prize, and Nobel Pr

heading: Deaths
txt: Marguerite Bise, French chef (b. 1898)

entities.title: Marguerite Bise
entities.description: Marguerite Valentine Bise was a French chef and restaurateur at her restaurant Auberge du Père Bise in Talloires, Haute-Savoie, France. In 1951, she became the third woman to win three Michelin stars.

heading: Deaths
txt: Geoffrey de Havilland, English pilot and engineer, designed the de Havilland Mosquito (b. 1882)

entities.title: De Havilland Mosquito
entities.description: The de Havilland DH.98 Mosquito is a British twin-engined, shoulder-winged multirole combat aircraft, introduced during the Second World War. Unusual in that its frame was constructed mostly of wood, it was nicknamed the "Wooden Wonder", or "Mossie". heading: Deaths
txt: Doris Lloyd, English actress (b. 1896)

entities.title: Doris Lloyd
entities.description: Hessy Doris Lloyd was an English–American film and stage actress. She is perhaps best known for her roles in The Time Machine (1960) and The Sound of Music (1965). During her career, Lloyd appeared in two Academy Award winners and four other nominees.

heading: Deaths
txt: E. L. Grant Watson, English-Australian biologist and author (b. 1885)

entities.title: E. L. Grant Watson
entities.description: Elliot Lovegood Grant Watson was a writer and biologist. Among some 40 books and many essays and short stories he wrote six 'Australian' novels and several scientific-philosophical works that challenge Darwinism, or the mechanism of evolutionary theory, as an entire explanation for the development of life on earth.

heading: Deaths
txt: Vaughn Monroe, American singer, trumpet player, bandleader, and actor (b. 1911)

entities.title: Vaughn Monroe
entities.description: Vaughn Wilton Monroe was an American baritone singer, trumpeter, big band leader, actor, and businessman, who was most popular in the 1940s and 1950s. He has two stars on the Hollywood Walk of Fame, one for recording and another for radio performance.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ivan Konev, Soviet Marshal and general (b. 1897)

heading: Deaths
txt: Raymond McCreesh, PIRA volunteer (b. 1957)

entities.title: Raymond McCreesh
entities.description: Raymond McCreesh was an Irish volunteer in the South Armagh Brigade of the Provisional Irish Republican Army (IRA). In 1976, he and two other IRA volunteers were captured while attempting to ambush a British Army observation post. McCreesh was one of the ten Irish republicans who died during the 1981 Irish hunger strike in the Maze Prison.

entities.title: PIRA
entities.description: The Irish Republican Army, also known as the Provisional Irish Republican Army, and informally as the Provos, was an Irish republican paramilitary organisation that sought to end British rule in Northern Ireland, facilitate Irish reunification and bring about an independent, socialist republic encompassing all of Ireland. It was the most active republican paramilitary group during the Troubles. It

heading: Deaths
txt: Patsy O'Hara, INLA volunteer (b. 1957)

entities.title: INLA
entities.description: The Irish National Liberation Army is an Irish republican socialist paramilitary group formed on 10 December 1974, during "the Troubles". It seeks to remove Northern Ireland from the United Kingdom and create a socialist republic encompassing all of Ireland. It is the paramilitary wing of the Irish Republican Socialist Party (IRSP).

heading: Deaths
txt: Kenneth Clark, English historian and author (b. 1903)

entities.title: Kenneth Clark
entities.description: Kenneth Mackenzie Clark, Baron Clark was a British art historian, museum director, and broadcaster. After running two important art galleries in the 1930s and 1940s, he came to wider public notice on television, presenting a succession of programmes on the arts during the 1950s and 1960s, culminating in the Civilisation series in 1969.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ann Little, American actress (b. 1891)

entities.title: Ann Little
entities.description: Ann Little, also known as Anna Little, was an American film actress whose career was most prolific during the silent film era of the early 1910s through the early 1920s. Today, most of her films are lost, with only twelve known to survive.

heading: Deaths

He co-founded the organization Concerned Artists of the Philippines (CAP), dedicated to helping artists address issues confronting the country, and the Free the Artist Movement. He was a member of the Coalition for the Res

heading: Deaths

entities.title: Prime Minister of India
entities.description: The Prime Minister of India, officially the Prime Minister of the Republic of India, is the leader of the executive branch of the Government of India. The prime minister is the chief adviser to the President of India and the head of the Union Council of Ministers. heading: Deaths
txt: Les Aspin, American captain and politician, 18th United States Secretary of Defense (b. 1938)

entities.title: Les Aspin
entities.description: Leslie Aspin Jr. was an American politician who served as the U.S. Representative for Wisconsin's 1st congressional district from 1971 to 1993 and as the 18th United States Secretary of Defense under President Bill Clinton from 1993 to 1994.

entities.title: United States Secretary of Defense
entities.description: The United States secretary of defense (SecDef) is the leader and chief executive officer of the United States Department of Defense, the executive department of the U.S. Armed Forces. The secretary of defense's position of command and authority over the military is second only to that of the president of the United States, who is the commander-in-chief. heading: Deaths
txt: Paul Delph, American singer-songwriter and producer (b. 1957)

entities.title: Paul Delph
entities.description: Paul Delph was a Los Angeles-based singer, songwriter, producer, engineer, and studio musician whose catalog includes work with many well-known recording artists from the late 1970s through the mid-1990s. Her 723 novels were translated into 38 languages and she continues to be referenced in the Guinness World Records for the most novels published in a single year in 1977.

heading: Deaths
txt: Niki de Saint Phalle, French-American sculptor and painter (b. 1930)

entities.title: Niki de Saint Phalle
entities.description: Niki de Saint Phalle was a French-American sculptor, painter, and filmmaker. Widely noted as one of the few female monumental sculptors, Saint Phalle was also known for her social commitment and work.

heading: Deaths
txt: Alejandro de Tomaso, Argentinian-Italian race car driver and businessman, founded De Tomaso (b. 1928)

entities.title: Alejandro de Tomaso
entities.description: Alejandro de Tomaso was a racing driver and businessman from Argentina. His name is sometimes seen in an Italianised form as Alessandro de Tomaso. He participated in two Formula One World Championship Grands Prix, debuting on 13 January 1957. He scored no championship points. He later founded the Italian sports car company De Tomaso Automobili in 1959.

entities.title: De Tomaso
entities.description: De Tomaso Automobili is an Italian car-manufacturing company. It was founded by the Argentine-born Alejandro de Tomaso (1928–2003) in Modena in 1959. It originally produced various prototypes and racing cars, including a Formula One car for Frank Williams's team in 1970. heading: Deaths

entities.title: Governor of Arkansas
entities.description: The Governor of Arkansas is the head of government of the U.S. state of Arkansas. The Governor is the head of the executive branch of the Arkansas government and is charged with enforcing state laws. They have the power to either approve or veto bills passed by the Arkansas General Assembly, to convene the legislature, and to grant pardons, except in cases of treason and impeachment.

heading: Deaths
txt: Deborah Berger, American outsider artist (b. 1956)

entities.title: Deborah Berger
entities.description: Deborah Berger was an American artist noted for her oeuvre of brightly colored textile works created in knitting and crochet. She is considered an outsider artist and a prodigy.

entities.title: Outsider art
entities.description: Outsider art is art by self-taught or naïve art makers. Typically, those labeled as outsider artists have little or no contact with the mainstream art world or art institutions. In many cases, their work is discovered only after their deaths. Often, outsider art illustrates extreme mental states, unconventional ideas, or elaborate fantasy worlds.

heading: Deaths
txt: Nick Menza, American drummer and songwriter (b. 1964)

entities.title: Nick Menza
entities.description: Nicholas Menza was an American musician best known as the former drummer for thrash metal band Megadeth from 1989–1998 and again in 2004 as well as one final return in 2014. He recorded drums on four of Megadeth's albums: Rust in Peace (1990), Countdown to Extinction (1992), Youthanasia (1994), and Cryptic Writings (1997).

heading: Deaths
txt: Rik Kuypers, Belgian film director (b. 1925)

entities.title: Rik Kuypers
entities.description: Rik Kuypers was a Belgian film director. He directed 29 films between 1947 and 1981. He co-directed the film Seagulls Die in the Harbour, which was entered into the 1956 Cannes Film Festival.

entities.description: A chancellor is a leader of a college or university, usually either the executive or ceremonial head of the university or of a university campus within a university system.

entities.title: George Mason University
entities.description: George Mason University is a public research university in Fairfax County, Virginia, near Fairfax City. The university was established in 1957 as the Northern Virginia branch of the University of Virginia, and became an independent university in 1972.
